parameters.year: year ("epoch") of the observation, a decimal numeric vector
parameters.distance: separation distance between the two stars, a numeric vector
parameters.authority: A simplified version of the notes giving just the attribution of authority of the observation, a character vector
parameters.notes: Herschel's notes on this observation, a character vector
parameters.weight: a subjective weight attributed to the accuracy of this observation, a numeric vector
parameters.posangle: recorded position angle between the two stars, a numeric vector

reference:
The data in Virginis come from the table on p. 35 of the “Micrometrical Measures”
paper.
description:
Description
In 1833 J. F. W. Herschel published two papers in the Memoirs of the Royal Astronomical Society
detailing his investigations of calculating the orbits of twin stars from observations of
their relative position angle and angular distance.
In the process, he invented the scatterplot, and the use of visual smoothing to obtain a reliable
curve that surpassed the accuracy of individual observations (Friendly & Denis, 2005).
His data on the recordings of the twin stars \gamma Virginis provide an
accessible example of his methods.
title: John F. W. Herschel's Data on the Orbit of the Twin Stars \gamma Virginis
format:
Virgins: A data frame with 18 observations on the following 6 variables giving
the measurements of position angle and angular distance between the central (brightest)
star and its twin, recorded by various observers over more than 100 years.
